#Text=Seed dormancy, germination requirements, and implications of herbicides for�Penstemon albidus�and�P. nitidus\rGregory A Cooper,�Gabrielle A Bolwerk,�A Joshua Leffler,�Lora B Perkins\rFirst published: 04 July 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14228\rAuthor contributions: all authors conceived the study design; GAC, GAB performed data collection, statistical analysis, and wrote the first draft of the manuscript; all authors contributed to editing the manuscript and gave final approval for publication.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Peter T�r�k\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE
#Text=\rAbstract.
#Text=Seed _based restoration is dependent on seed germination, and poor germination can cause restoration failure.
#Text=Many restoration failures can be attributed to a lack of knowledge of germination characteristics, species _specific seed dormancy, or the effects of widely used herbicides on germination.

#Text=White penstemon (Penstemon albidus) and Waxleaf penstemon (P. nitidus) are native to the Northern Great Plains region of North America, and increased germination of these species would contribute to improved restoration in the region.
#Text=We performed two concurrent experiments to determine: (1) the germination requirements and dormancy class of these species; and (2) the effects of herbicides on germination.
#Text=To determine germination requirements, we applied pretreatments (scarification, smoke, and KNO3) and three durations (2, 4, and 8 weeks) of cold and warm stratification.

#Text=To test the effects of herbicides on germination, three commonly used herbicides (atrazine, trifluralin, and 2,4 _D) were applied at six concentrations (100, 50, 10, 1, 0.1, and 0% of the recommended field application rate).
#Text=Germination characteristics indicate both species express physiological dormancy.
#Text=Physiological dormancy denotes an embryo with low growth potential that is unable to overcome mechanical constraints but can be alleviated with proper temperature cues.
#Text=Both species required cold stratification, with�P. nitidus�needing a longer period (8 weeks) than�P. albidus�(4 weeks).
#Text=Final germination percentage of�P. albidus�decreased with higher doses of 2,4 _D but was not affected by atrazine or trifluralin.
#Text=These experiments help to create protocol for the use of our study species, as well as other species, in restoration plantings.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Native plant species have varying germination requirements and dormancy classes; thus, restoration practices will need to be species _specific, as even species of the same genus can have different requirements.\r* Understanding the germination requirements of native plants and the knowledge to break seed dormancy will lead to more immediate success in seed _based restoration efforts.\r* Herbicides can affect the germination of native plant species, so further emphasis should be placed on studying seed _based restoration in areas adjacent to row _crop agriculture, as seen in the fragmented landscapes of the Northern Great Plains.\r* Protocol can be used to elucidate the germination requirements of other native species outside of the Northern Great Plains by adjusting temperatures to reflect those of other environments.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=Grasslands are important ecosystems worldwide as they provide a variety of ecosystem services, many of which are provided by native plants (Plant Conservation Alliance�2021).
#Text=However, native plants are lost when ecosystems, such as the grasslands of the Northern Great Plains (NGP), are converted to row _crop agriculture (Trowbridge et al�2017).

#Text=To combat this loss, land managers practice ecological restoration, the intentional activity of initiating or accelerating the recovery of an ecosystem in relation to health, integrity, and sustainability (SER�2004), often by sowing seeds of native species.
#Text=A lack of knowledge about germination can decrease seed _based restoration success (Broadhurst et al�2016).
#Text=Thus, increased comprehension of germination traits and herbicide effects is needed to improve outcomes using native plants in restoration.
#Text=Seed dormancy is one factor that may affect the germination success of seeds in restoration.
#Text=A dormant seed is incapable of germination even in suitable environmental conditions (Finch _Savage & Leubner _Metzger�2006).

#Text=In natural populations, dormancy enables seedling success by dispersing germination over several seasons or limiting germination to only when environmental conditions are most favorable for subsequent seedling establishment (Meyer�2006).
#Text=However, dormancy can keep restoration seed from establishing vegetation in a timely manner.
#Text=Deciphering which of the five dormancy classes seeds express can help practitioners develop a better protocol for seeding dormant species at restoration sites.
#Text=Another potential factor affecting germination is seed exposure to agricultural chemicals, specifically herbicides (Wagner & Nelson�2014).
#Text=A seed may be exposed to herbicide during field preparation for restoration, or from drift from application in adjacent agricultural fields.
#Text=Due to the extensive fragmentation of the historic grasslands in the NGP (Perkins et al�2019), many restoration sites occur adjacent to or surrounded by agricultural fields.
#Text=Herbicides used on these fields can drift from the target field of application to nontarget grasslands (Brain et al�2019).
#Text=Even 10�20% of the herbicide field application rate can negatively affect reproduction in native plants (Olszyk et al�2017).
#Text=Below _recommended application rates of herbicides can also negatively impact seed germination (Triques et al�2021).
#Text=Due to evidence from previous studies on nontarget species, we suspect that our study species will have reduced germination when exposed to differing levels of herbicide.
#Text=However, there is a knowledge gap regarding the effects of the below _recommended application rates of various herbicides on the germination of different nontarget plants.

#Text=Our study focuses on two perennial forbs, White penstemon (Penstemon albidus) and Waxleaf penstemon (P. nitidus), to investigate germination biology in the context of increasing seed _based restoration success.
#Text=A large genus (>250 species) native to North America (Lindgren & Schaaf�2004),�Penstemon�are an integral part of American landscapes and an important component of ecological restoration.
#Text=Within the Great Plains,�P. albidusranges from Alberta, Canada, to Texas, United States; and�P. nitidus�from Alberta, Canada, to Colorado, United States (USDA _NRCS�2023).

#Text=�Penstemon albidus�grows to a height of 15�30 cm in sandy or silty loam, and bloom white flowers between April and June; whereas�P. nitidusgrows to a height of 30 cm on dry hills and slopes, and blooms blue flowers in April and May (Nold�1999).
#Text=Germination requirements have been documented for other�Penstemon�species (Meyer & Kitchen�1994), and many have been classified as physiologically dormant (Baskin & Baskin�2014).

#Text=Physiological dormancy can be broken by chemical cues (smoke and KNO3), temperature cues (Kildisheva et al�2020), and scarification (Finch _Savage & Leubner _Metzger�2006), all methods that have induced germination for other�Penstemon�species (Flessner & Stubbendieck�1989; Raeber & Lee�1991; Lindgren & Schaaf�2004).
#Text=Therefore, we suspect that if dormant, our study species would express physiological dormancy.
#Text=Research on pretreatments, dormancy, and herbicide effects has seldom been published on�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus.

#Text=Land managers and restoration practitioners have had difficulty germinating�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus�in restoration settings and have considered the species as high _priority to study and establish germination protocol (W.
#Text=Velman 2022, United States Bureau of Land Management, personal communication).
#Text=Some protocol exists for these species, but much of it does not have a scientific basis.

#Text=Occasional gardening resources suggest seed stratification, the process of simulating natural environmental conditions, but do not specify the exact stratification conditions required (Reese�2016), which can affect�Penstemon�germination (Meyer & Kitchen�1994).
#Text=Although valuable, other published protocol collected through notes and personal communication (Love & Akins�2020) also lack data and cannot be reviewed with academic rigor.
#Text=Determining germination protocol through repeatable measures is the best method for increasing species _specific germination success.

#Text=To determine the precise germination treatments required for�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus, and identify the associated dormancy class if expressed, we tested the effects of several dormancy _breaking treatments (cold and warm stratification with and without scarification, smoke, or KNO3) on final germination.
#Text=To determine the tolerance of study species to common herbicides, we tested the effects of three agricultural herbicides at six concentrations on final germination.

#Text=The overall aim of these experiments was to evaluate and better understand germination biology so that practitioners could apply germination characteristics to restoration settings and increase germination success.
#Text=Methods.

#Text=To increase germination knowledge of�Penstemon albidus�and�P. nitidus, we performed two separate experiments with a concurrent start date, a germination requirements experiment and an herbicide effects experiment, to better understand the germination biology of�Penstemon�for applied restoration.
#Text=Research was conducted at South Dakota State University (SDSU) in Brookings, South Dakota, United States.
#Text=Seeds of�P. albidus�were sourced from the Native Plant Initiative at SDSU, and�P. nitidus�seeds were sourced commercially from Western Native Seed (Coaldale, CO, U.S.A.).
#Text=After procurement, seeds were stored in sealed plastic bags in a dry, refrigerated environment at 5degreesC.
#Text=Seeds of�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus�were stored for less than 9 months and 3 months, respectively, before testing.
#Text=Seeds were randomly assigned to treatments in all experiments.
#Text=Before germination experiments, a tetrazolium chloride test, as explained in Miller (2010), was performed for viability on untreated seeds of each species.
#Text=Two replicates of 100 seeds were soaked in deionized water for approximately 12 hours at room temperature.
#Text=Seeds were removed from water and then soaked in a 1.0% tetrazolium solution for approximately 12 hours in darkness at 35degreesC before dissection and analysis.
#Text=Germination Requirements Experiment\rAn experiment on pretreatment and temperature conditions was conducted to determine the germination requirements for�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus.
#Text=Seeds were pretreated with scarification, smoke, or KNO3.
#Text=Seeds that received a scarification pretreatment were placed in an electric scarifier (Fred Forsberg & Sons, Inc.) lined with 600 _grit sandpaper, which was run in 10 _second intervals.
#Text=Between intervals, seeds were viewed under a dissection microscope and considered scarified when seed coats appeared scratched or damaged.
#Text=Seeds in the smoke pretreatment were placed in a 77 _quart container and spread in a single layer.
#Text=A Breville Smoking Gun was used to burn 1.5 g of wood, which applied smoke to the container.
#Text=Seeds were sealed for 20 minutes until the container was opened to let the smoke dissipate.
#Text=A 20 mM dosage was used for the KNO3�pretreatment.

#Text=KNO3�is commonly used to promote germination (Kildisheva et al�2020) and 20 mM is the recommended concentration for germination testing by the Association of Official Seed Analysts (Copeland & McDonald�2012).
#Text=In this pretreatment, the germination paper was initially moistened with KNO3.
#Text=All other pretreatments, including the control, used deionized water to moisten the germination paper.
#Text=The control was left untreated.
#Text=The experiment also tested temperature conditions, where seeds were either cold or warm stratified for 2, 4, or 8 weeks.
#Text=Stratification methods were based on Tilini et al (2016), which tested the germination of�P. gibbensii�and�P. haydenii.
#Text=Germination chambers (Seedburo Equipment Co.) had 12 _hour photoperiods, and alternating light, dark temperatures.

#Text=Seeds were cold (2/5degreesC) and warm stratified (16/29degreesC) in moist environments, representative of a 30 _year average of winter (February) and summer (July) temperatures from across the NGP (NOAA�2021).
#Text=Our germination chambers were unable to run below 2degreesC.

#Text=Although the average low air temperature for winter in the NGP is approximately  10degreesC (NOAA�2021), snow cover in cold winters can keep soil temperatures nearer to 0degreesC (Decker et al�2003), a close estimate to our experimental temperature setting.

#Text=After stratification, seeds were transferred to conditions representing typical spring planting temperatures (6/18degreesC) in the NGP, taken from a 30 _year average of spring (May) temperatures across the NGP (NOAA�2021).
#Text=Seeds were incubated in spring temperatures for 8 weeks until the termination of the experiment, as 8 weeks in ideal conditions is sufficient time to allow germination (Baskin & Baskin�2003).
#Text=Seeds also remained in each of the three temperature conditions for 16 weeks as temperature controls.
#Text=The experiment was set up in a factorial design between pretreatments and temperature conditions.
#Text=Treatments consisted of five replicates of 50 seeds.
#Text=For each replicate, seeds were placed on germination paper, moistened with deionized water (or KNO3), and placed into a 4    6  reclosable bag.
#Text=Replicates were placed in germination chambers (as described above) and paper was remoistened with deionized water as needed, regardless of pretreatment.

#Text=Initially, germination was to be recorded only after stratification treatments; however, because previous studies have shown�Penstemon�can germinate during cold stratification (Meyer & Kitchen�1994), we decided to score germination from the start of the experiment.
#Text=The number of germinants was recorded daily for the first 7 days of the experiment and then approximately every third day until finishing the intended temperature regime.

#Text=Herbicide Effects Experiment\rConcurrent to and separate from the germination requirements experiment, we investigated the effects of a range of concentrations representative of herbicide drift of three common agricultural herbicides (atrazine, trifluralin, and 2,4 _D) on the germination of�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus.
#Text=Seeds were not pretreated (including stratification), in accordance with the seeding practices of published ecological restoration studies (Piper et al�2007; Alstad et al�2018).
#Text=For each chemical, six concentrations (100, 50, 10, 1, 0.1, and 0% of the recommended field application rate for commercial corn production) were used.
#Text=The different concentrations of herbicide were intended to simulate the range of herbicide that a native seed adjacent to agricultural fields may be exposed to following restoration seeding.
#Text=Germination paper was saturated with the given herbicide solution, and then one sheet was placed in a 4    6  reclosable bag and sealed.
#Text=Once all the papers for a species and herbicide were saturated, seeds of a single species were placed in each bag.
#Text=We used eight replicates of 25 seeds for each chemical by concentration treatment.
#Text=The bags were put into the germination chamber (Sheldon Mfg.
#Text=Inc.) set to a 12 _hour photoperiod (6/18degreesC) to reflect typical spring planting temperatures in the region (NOAA�2021).
#Text=The number of germinants was counted daily for the first 7 days of the experiment and then every other day thereafter until 45 days had passed.
#Text=If germination of a given species still occurred at day 45, we continued to count germination every other day until day 91, when the experiment was terminated.

#Text=Statistical Analysis\rAuto _Germ (Richardson et al�2018) was used to process count data into germination metrics, and R programming (v4.1.2; R Core Team�2021) was used to test for significant influences of pretreatments, temperature conditions, and herbicides (Table�S1).
#Text=Germination percentage was calculated as the percentage of seeds that germinated at the end of the experiment out of the total number of seeds in the replicate.
#Text=Data were analyzed with an analysis of variance.
#Text=The germination requirements experiment used a Sidak _correction as a multiple comparison test.
#Text=The goal of the germination requirements experiment was to determine which treatments increased germination compared to the control.
#Text=None of the pretreatments increased germination compared to the control (p > 0.05); therefore, the interaction between main effects was not included in the analysis.
#Text=The herbicide effects experiment used Tukey's honestly significant difference (HSD) as a multiple comparison test.

#Text=Although the experiments were concurrent, because they used separate germination chambers with different volumes, airflow, and light intensities, treatments between the two experiments were not compared.
#Text=Results.
#Text=Germination Requirements\rSeeds had viability of 90 and 73% for�Penstemon albidus�and�P. nitidus, respectively.
#Text=After 4 weeks, neither species surpassed 12% germination for any pretreatment or temperature condition, despite high viability (Tables�S2�&�S3).
#Text=Temperature conditions influenced the final germination percentage of�P. albidus�(F[8,144] = 360.4,�p�value � 0.001) (Fig�1A).
#Text=Seeds exposed only to spring temperatures (6/18degreesC) germinated to 9% after 16 weeks.
#Text=Warm stratified seeds germinated best (61%) after 16 weeks at 16/29degreesC.
#Text=Highest overall germination was recorded from cold stratified treatments: 4 and 8 weeks (followed by spring temperatures), and 16 weeks (ranging between 86 and 94%; Table�S4).

#Text=The KNO3�pretreatment significantly reduced the final germination percentage compared to scarification (F[3,144] = 4.2,�p�value = 0.007), but no pretreatment had a significant effect compared to the control (Table�S5).
#Text=Figure 1\rGermination of�Penstemon albidus�(A) and�P. nitidus�(B) in different temperature conditions.
#Text=Germination during the initial temperature (black) shows when seeds germinated during the stratification period and controls.

#Text=This includes warm stratification (16/29degreesC) of 2 weeks (W2), 4 weeks (W4), and 8 weeks (W8); cold stratification (2/5degreesC) of 2 weeks (C2), 4 weeks (C4), and 8 weeks (C8); spring control (SC, 6/18degreesC); warm control (WC, 16/29degreesC); and cold control (CC, 2/5degreesC).
#Text=Controls did not change temperatures and spent 16 weeks in the assigned temperature condition.

#Text=Germination post _temperature change shows germination that occurred after the seeds rotated and were incubated for 8 weeks, in the typical spring temperature conditions (6/18degreesC; hatched).
#Text=Temperature conditions influenced the final germination percentage of�P. nitidus�(F[8,144] = 134.9,�p�value � 0.001) (Fig�1B).
#Text=Seeds exposed only to spring temperatures (6/18degreesC) germinated to 1% after 16 weeks.
#Text=Warm stratified seeds only germinated to 3�5%.
#Text=Highest overall germination was recorded from cold stratified treatments: 8 weeks (followed by spring temperatures), and 16 weeks (33%; Table�S4).

#Text=The KNO3�pretreatment significantly reduced the final germination percentage compared to scarification and smoke (F[3,144] = 7.4,�p�value � 0.001), but no pretreatment had a significant effect compared to the control (Table�S5).
#Text=Herbicide Effects\rFinal germination percentage of�P. albidus�was influenced by herbicide concentration (Fig�2).

#Text=Final germination percentage for�P. albidus�was affected by exposure to 2,4 _D (F[5,42] = 35.7,�p value < 0.001), but not atrazine (F[5,42] = 2.3,�p�value = 0.067) or trifluralin (F[5,42] = 0.8,�p�value = 0.055; Table�S6).
#Text=Higher doses of 2,4 _D (50 and 100% recommended application rate) significantly decreased germination of�P. albidus�compared to lower doses and the control.
#Text=Figure 2\rGermination of�Penstemon albidus�in different concentrations of 2,4 _D.
#Text=Bars represent +/ _ SE.
#Text=Different letters indicate statistically different values using Tukey's HSD (  = 0.05).
#Text=Seeds of�P. nitidus�in the control group and herbicide treated groups exhibited very low germination percentages, with a maximum final germination percentage of 7% (Table�S7).
#Text=Among all herbicides, a minimum final germination percentage of less than 1% occurred in multiple treatments.
#Text=Due to low final germination percentages, we were unable to make any relevant statistical conclusions for�P. nitidus.

#Text=Discussion\rGermination Requirements\rHighest germination of�Penstemon albidus�was achieved with at least 4 weeks of cold stratification, and that of�P. nitidus�with at least 8 weeks of cold stratification.
#Text=Exposure to cold temperatures is required for many other�Penstemon�to increase germination and emergence (Lindgren & Schaaf�2004).
#Text=From our results, we infer that both species express physiological dormancy, a dormancy class often associated with stratification requirements (Ruiz _Talonia et al�2022).

#Text=The presence of stratification requirements prevents seeds from germinating prematurely in unfavorable conditions during winter (Tang et al�2019), which is advantageous in the temperate and unpredictable springs of the NGP.
#Text=This classification is consistent with several other�Penstemon�that have previously been analyzed for dormancy (Baskin & Baskin�2014).
#Text=The presence of dormancy indicates the importance of treating restoration seed in order to increase germination success.
#Text=Although we expected germination to occur only after the stratification period, we found that the study species germinated during the cold stratification periods as well.

#Text=Germination during cold stratification treatments has been observed in many other species of�Penstemon(Meyer & Kitchen�1994; Tilini et al�2016), in addition to other temperate forbs (Kildisheva et al�2019).
#Text=Because germination occurred during our cold stratification periods,�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus�would likely begin germination phenology in late winter.
#Text=Because germination during cold stratification treatments in laboratory settings may not prove beneficial for sowing efforts, we recommend our study species be seeded over _winter in the field.
#Text=If overwintered,�P. albidus�should be direct _seeded with at least a month of winter temperatures remaining (</ 5degreesC), and 2 months for�P. nitidus.
#Text=Seeds could be direct _seeded in early winter, as we did not detect any detrimental impacts from exposure to cold temperatures up to 16 weeks.
#Text=However, leaving seeds on the landscape for long periods of time will expose seeds to threats such as predation and wind disturbance (Pellish et al�2018).
#Text=In light of a changing climate, further steps should be taken to investigate species in the NGP that require cold stratification.

#Text=Shifting winter regimes, such as earlier snowmelt, can cause phenological shifts in plant recruitment (Slatyer et al�2022), which may impact seed germination and establishment for�Penstemon�species.
#Text=Herbicide Effects\rGermination of�P. albidus�varied among herbicides and concentrations.
#Text=Final germination percentage of�P. albidus�was unaffected by exposure to a range of concentrations of atrazine and trifluralin.
#Text=Final germination percentage decreased with exposure to higher concentrations of 2,4 _D.

#Text=At 50 and 100% field application rate of 2,4 _D, the average final germination percentage was 5%, whereas the average final germination percentage for 0�10% field application rate of 2,4 _D was 44%.
#Text=The variation in germination among herbicides and concentrations can inform restoration uses of�P. albidus.

#Text=Similar to other�Penstemon�(P. acuminatus,�P. deustus, and�P. speciosus), which can survive and grow despite herbicide presence (Shock et al�2010),�P. albidus�is a good candidate for restoration adjacent to agricultural fields using atrazine or trifluralin.
#Text=Conversely,�P. albidus�seeds planted adjacent to agricultural fields using 2,4 _D may experience reduced germination.
#Text=However, seeds planted further away from agricultural field margins may germinate without issue, as they are tolerant to low amounts of 2,4 _D.

#Text=Actual herbicide impacts on germination in restoration sites may vary depending on factors such as air temperature, wind velocity and direction, application method, and herbicide volatility, as these factors may affect the dose of herbicide present in drift (Dexter�1993).

#Text=Due to the very low final germination percentages of�P. nitidus�among herbicides, concentrations, and control treatments, no analysis was conducted as the results would not be ecologically relevant.
#Text=Because�P. nitidus�had such poor germination, we suggest using alternative methods to further study this species' response to herbicides.

#Text=As determined by the concurrent germination requirements experiment, breaking the dormancy of the seeds and providing proper environmental conditions to promote germination would provide more reliable germination in�P. nitidus�if the experiment was repeated.
#Text=This research will lead to increased restoration success when using�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus.

#Text=Sowing�P. albidus�and�P. nitidus�at least 1 and 2 months before the end of winter (respectively) may allow for ideal stratification temperature and length, which, through increased germination percentages, can increase the number of plants that emerge and eventually reach maturity.

#Text=Atrazine and trifluralin at or below _recommended application rates do not hinder the germination of�P. albidus, making the species a strong candidate to consider for restorations near agricultural fields using these herbicides.

#Text=Restoration practitioners should reduce�P. albidus�exposure to 2,4 _D or avoid sowing in restoration sites adjacent to agricultural fields using 2,4 _D, as�P. albidus�germination may be hindered by half to full recommended rates of the herbicide.
#Text=Acknowledgments\rResearch was supported by U.S.
#Text=Bureau of Land Management (SA2200088); USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture (2018 _67020 _27809); and American Penstemon Society 2022 Special Project Grants.
#Text=The authors would like to thank M.
#Text=White and L.
#Text=Cutler for their assistance in experimental preparation and data analysis, respectively, and three anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments and editorial suggestions.
#Text=We acknowledge that author L.B.P. is an editor for Restoration Ecology and receives no compensation.
